newsitem.title: CHINA: Zhejiang Expressway confident on 2nd half.
newsitem.headline: Zhejiang Expressway confident on 2nd half.

text.p: China's Zhejiang Expressway Co Ltd said on Tuesday it is confident of achieving its earnings forecast for 1997 despite the construction of two interchanges affecting traffic volume of its Hangzhou-Ningbo Expressway.
"We are confident about achieving the profit forecast set in the prospectus by increasing income and reducing costs through various channels," chairman Geng Xiaoping told a telephone conference.
It posted an interim net profit of HK$125.23 million ($16.17 million) for 1997 against its annual profit forecast before extraordinary items of not less than 200 million yuan (HK$186.90).
"Profitability shall be increased by providing ancillary facilities, for example, car maintenance and petrol stations, shops, restaurants, and billboard advertising along the expressway," Geng said.
The Hangzhou city government was spending about 200 million yuan to build two interchanges and elevated bridges along the Hangzhou city junction of the expressway to ease congestion.
Geng said the construction, which started in June and will be completed in end-November, would take away a maximum of seven to eight percent of the company's revenue in the second half.
"After the completion of the interchanges, the congestion problem will be fundamentally solved and is expect to greatly lift our traffic volume," he said.
Zhejiang Expressway, representing the Zhejiang provincial government's main vehicle for expressway development, wholly owns and operates the Hanzhou-Ningbo Expressway.

The company was also actively reviewing the feasibility of investment in the Huzhou section of the Hangzhou-Nanjing Expressway and the Shangyu-Sanmen Road as disclosed in the prospectus, the chairman said.
Wilbur Smith Associates Ltd has been appointed as traffic and engineering consultants to conduct a study on the traffic flow and construction costs of the projects.
"If the result of the study shows an internal rate of return of 20 percent or above, the company will consider implementing the proposed investment in the second half of 1997," he said.
The chairman said the investment sum in the two projects had not been finalised yet.

But Geng said the city's transport department had approved the total investment of the 35-km long Huzhou section at about 1.222 billion yuan and the 142 km long Shanyu-Sanmen highway was expected to cost about 4.2 billion yuan to build.
"Generally speaking we aim for a controlling stake in the projects," he said.
Zhejiang Expressway raised a total of about 3.524 billion yuan from a H-share flotation in May.
The company had used 270 million yuan to repay bank loans and the balance was placed on short-term deposit in banks or invested in treasury bonds, Geng said.
-- Hong Kong Newsroom (852) 2843 6369 ($ = 7.74 Hong Kong Dollars)
